description: From Middle English quilte, quylte, from Anglo-Norman quilte and Old French coilte, cuilte (compare French couette), from Latin culcita. Doublet of quoit.

entries.meaning: A bed covering consisting of two layers of fabric stitched together, with insulation between, often having a decorative design.
examples: My grandmother is going to sew a quilt.

entries.meaning: A roll of material with sound-absorbing properties, used in soundproofing.
A quilted skirt worn by women.

verbs.description: quilt (third-person singular simple present quilts, present participle quilting, simple past and past participle quilted)

entries.meaning: To construct something, such as clothing, using the same technique.
(UK, slang, obsolete) To beat or thrash.
examples: I am glad, said Mr. Slick, that cussed critter, that schoolmaster, hasn't yet woke up. I'm most afeerd if he had aturned out afore we started, I should have quilted him, for that talk of his last night sticks in my crop considerable hard.
